p: ‘Education-information’, the most voted attribute, refers to “opportune, equitable and universal access to information and education” (Aldunce et al. 2014b, p. 18). It is necessary to consider two aspects related to education. First, this topic has emerged as a main attribute in other studies, for example, Olwig ( 2012) and (Aldunce et al. 2015), who studied local understandings of resilience in Ghana and Australia, respectively. Second, it is necessary to understand recent Chilean history. The major student movements since the return of democracy were developed in 2006 and 2011, changing the policy agenda and generating a massive demand for public education (Fleet 2011; Cabalin 2012). The influence of this movement on citizens was relevant: for example, according to national polls, 80 % of the Chilean population supported the student movement (Cabalin 2012).
